Aya Hrout
Programs Director at Jordan Youth Innovation Forum. A Global Shaper member under the world economic forum. Master’s in Strategic Human Resources management, believing the human factor is the key success factor for businesses and communities growth as a whole.
Annie Seferian
Annie Seferian - Director of the LAU Innovation Center. Aggregated and collective-learning will always benefit the greater community. We at LAU Innovation Center support innovation, entrepreneurship and creative solutions from our young students and beyond, by fostering engagement and adaptability to grow ideas to fully scalable businesses. 
Bilal Ghalib
Bilal is the co-founder and Head of Research at Bloom looking to help unlock human potential for positive change. Currently focused on 
Israa Asaad 
Israa Asaad - is an Innovation Consultant. She has a Master's in Engineering Management and is Lean Six Sigma Black Belt certified. She is a startup analyst and mentor. Israa offers high quality agile coaching and advisory to startup founders and entrepreneurs. She has supported more than 30 startups across industries and stages. Israa also guides the startups in their journeys of optimizing their processes within their target markets.
Layal and Mohammed Ghamloush
Founders at Sikka Saida Community Centre, a free, open and safe space that focuses on empowering  people to thrive.
Lyndon Rego


Mohammed Al-Afifi
Mohammed H. Alafifi is a university lecturer with +15 years of experience in digital marketing, entrepreneurship, and freelancing. He has a master’s degree from the University of Brussels and works as an academic lecturer at the University College of Applied Sciences in Gaza - Palestine. 
He is a consultant and trainer with many national and international institutions such as UNDP, UNRWA, Catholic Relief Services, Islamic Relief, Global Innovation Catalysts, UCAS Technology Incubators, and many more. 
Sarah Makhoul
Dr. Sarah Makhoul - is an accomplished professional with a diverse range of experience and expertise. Currently, she serves as the Head of the Finance Department at the FSEG-3rd Branch of the Lebanese University (LU), where she also holds the position of Associate Professor. In addition, Dr. Makhoul is a Financial Manager for GIL-UNICEF-LU, overseeing important financial operations and initiatives.
Beyond her work in academia and finance, Dr. Makhoul is also an active volunteer at CentreMINE-LU, working to support and uplift her local community. She is also an Instructor at Antonine University (AU), where she shares her knowledge and experience with the next generation of business leaders.
Rim El Khattabi
Rim El Khattabi -  Program and Fund Manager at the Moroccan incubator Bidaya. Bidaya aims to support projects with a social, environmental, or cultural impact, all across Morocco. 
At Bidaya, we are dedicated to nurturing wellbeing within our team: collaboration between team members is based on open communication and positive relationships. Recognizing the importance of work-life balance, Bidaya encourages its team members to maintain a healthy equilibrium by emphasizing the value of personal time and setting clear boundaries.



Authors: Bilal, 
Collaborative notes:
Sharing notes together:
Milia: Wellbeing is everything in the workspace being stable. 
Everything stable economically, physically and socially. 
Sarah: Well-being is an ongoing process, and it's important to adapt your approach based on the unique needs and challenges of our stakeholder with the environment 
the environment = various parties that may have an effect on our behavior
Amanda: added, And to live whenever and wherever we are in a friendly environment surrounded by nature, love, family and team work
Annie: Wellbeing can be collective and individual
Rim: well-being stems from the knowledge of having a safe space, a safety net, in your environment
Dara: wellbeing means feeling safe in my body, mind and heart in harmony with my surroundings
Aya: the state of mind due to internal and external factors, that helps us feel at peace inside 
Rida: Physical well-being → good diet and regular exercise; Mental Wellbeing; aligning thoughts, words, and actions + moderate rest :)
Munir: Having a “personal toolkit” for how to respond when stressful or challenging situations arise, both as individuals and as a group / community 
Peter: Have a sustainable and flexible working place that allows the employee have their freedom and flexibility to achieve their duties and goals. 
Dima: It is a balance between work and personal life. They complement each other and reflect on our well-being


Mental stress can manifest in the body
Interesting concept: EnterTraining
Workload and Stress Management - is how to manage with well-being at work!! … stressful environment can be hard to handl ! and to coop with ! (that’s why all research highlight the importance of time management)




Dr. Sarah Makhoul- 
Head of finance department at LU faculty of science
Career center at LU.
How to combine psychology in science/ financial aspects. 
How to prioritize: Health/Mental Health/Financial Health. 
Massive demands - everyone wants to talk to you, demands on your knowledge and experience. 
Few times per day I divide my day - 2 hours I focus on writing articles. 2 hours on campus 2 hours being with family. 
Dara taught me how to put my cellphone on do not disturb. 
It’s not available, people demand us to be available 24/7. We need to sleep at some point. 
One of my students called me at 11PM - Dr. you’re online can I ask a question!

Annie Seferian - 
Anecdote during corona: Lots of fear of corona, management was realizing it’s important to talk about wellbeing and mental health for the orgnaization. 
It went beyond our KPIs. 
If employees are in trouble, talk to eVPs - suddenly it became top priority. Even above other KPIs.
Mckinsey article: social financial, educational, financial and freedom. 
Takes effort to focus on the culture of getting work done and doing it in a peaceful way rather than “clocking in 9-5” - without engagement / caring. Wellbeing should be directed towards getting things done in a collaborative setup.
Ask them if they’re doing this role/task. What if I’m doing it on my own time/expense. 

Mohammed Alafifi - 
When we talk about stress we think it should be more for the smaller companies. It’s interesting that it’s larger for the larger organizations.
It’s easier to work with and help adapt the culture in smaller companies.

Aya JYIF - 46% of the causes of stress is the workload 28% other - family/social life.
Work is the main cause of stress worldwide
300 billion dollars of losses - absenteeism 
Financial Costs of Job Stress | CPH-NEW | ResearchUniversity of Massachusetts Lowellhttps://www.uml.edu › ... › Stress@Work
Talking about stress and how we can address that. 
Aya is open to talk with people about stress management at work as well as with the teams we train. 
Managers have a responsibility - AND - individuals have a responsibility 
Lots of factors managers can work
We must focus on the human side - 
There are a lot of benefits - If this is what it takes to convince employers to consider wellbeing

Bilal Question: **Startups and our early stage entrepreneurs - (including myself) - how do I allow myself to rest and have a balanced day with family / break / and work while still making sure the company doesn’t collapse.

You need to sett the boundaries … you need to say that to your self 1st, you are important as much as the team … you are important as much as the enterprise ! if you collapse the team will collaps as well, and so the enterprise ! 
You set boundaries … set the list of priorities on your agenda ( your agenda is your fram work! Its, your road toward your goal); get to say NO, you can’t please all people arround ! have a clear working hours ! (from 9am to 5pm per exemple ) ….  

Rim: How do you set boundaries?
Participants might call in the evening, calls/emails, etc. 
All teams are in an emergency state - they have 100000 tasks and your response is needed IMMEDIATELY. 
Make boundaries and set it so it’s clear that we’re available only during workhours. 

Other team members shouldn’t interrupt during break days. 
BG: How do you set boundaries when we may be understaffed/underresourced? 
Rim: Sometimes we have to.. We establish a support system. 
Whenever you’re free you can rest. When there’s rush time-rush, and when you can rest you can rest. 
Rim: Support each other across departments. 

Mohammed/Layla: Agency really cares about the wellbeing of their staff. We are FORCED to take days off. Contractors are paid by hour and the organization pushes people to take time off.

We are two of us. We don’t overload ourselves. We have a wheel of life chart 

IQ - Intelligence quotient
EQ - Emotional quotient 
BQ - Body quotient 
SQ - spiritual quotient 

Sometimes we have to GO TO THE BEACH with our two little girls. 

This is a great sign of how to influence culture!

Mohammed/Layal: Checkin channel - some people come in and say “I don’t feel well, I can’t work today.” 

Dara: Bloom takes a break twice a week a year so EVERYONE is off at the same time. That way it really helps people really relax because there is no work that’s “piled up” when people come back 
We can checkin with our whole self. 
Cosmic Centaurs Blueprint for an Intentional Summer

DMN: Reflecting is not a takeaway from work time. It’s an enabler for effective work time.
We are all the entrepreneur of our own lives. Make the smart decisions over short/medium/long to go towards the direction we want to go is critical.  
When you’re a founder, you have an effect on other people’s lives as well. Good decisions on prioritization is really important. We only have 24 hours a day. 


Aya: 
Work/life balance - impressive. We have to remind ourselves to speak up. 
Sometimes managers just DON’T KNOW - d


Once you know the vision / purpose of what you’re doing - it helps with feeling fine/comfortable because your vision is aligned.

Consider personal/professional goals. What about personal development goals? 
What do //you// desire to learn to develop in terms of skills. 

Universal Skills? Public speaking skills. I want to keep learning - my own 

Mohammed and Layal: Reflection quote: "I am not who you think I am; I am not who I think I am; I am who I think you think I am"

How does this relate to how we design our entrepreneurial programs? 

When you understand yourself and see how you are a part of the systems you’re a part of helps you act skillfully. 

Peter Abdel Karim: Entrepreneur, a part of many programs, digital marketing/graphic design/many hats.

From my learning journey. Being in a supportive community / learning from others / hear from other people’s feedback. <3 working with people who give constructive feedback.


Essentialism - The Disciplined Pursuit of Less by Greg McKeown

The businessman and the fisherman - The Storytellers

Layal: All of my favorite projects were probono projects, causes were amazing. Made by people who can’t afford to do it. Yet they were the projects I LOVED the most. 
Makes you feel good to know you’re working for a cause that’s contributing to a community. Sometimes it’s much better than being paid a ton that you don’t enjoy or doesn’t do any good. 

What if we can do more of the ones that align most with our values. 
So cool to not pass on. Put their heart in. 

BG: Values - Creating values - Exchanging values - Creating economies. 

Mohammed Sikka: Values and Beliefs - we need to talk about this. 
The five major pieces to the life puzzle - Book by Jim Rohn


Mohammed Alafifi: Business is driven by profit. Wellbeing. Different talking about business VS talking about wellbeing in an NGO / institution. 
As businesses we are driven by profit and we must change the mindset of businesses so they understand the importance of wellbeing.
Maybe we can create an argument that shows businesses that they are creating a better profit/revenue long term. 
Reduce brain drain from businesses. 
Are we going to focus on businesses or institutions? We have different priorities. We have a level of professionalism that’s different. 
The rules for businesses. 
For small businesses it’s different than for large businesses. 

Rida: End of the day we’re humans. Leader shared, 
“At the end of the day we are people working with people to serve people”

**One-Page Summary: Collaborative Notes - EON Thriving Together ToT Open House**

This document summarizes the collaborative notes from the EON Thriving Together ToT Open House, which focused on empowering organizations to foster wellbeing and engagement for sustainable impact. The session included panelists and participants who shared their insights and practices related to wellbeing in the workplace.

The meeting notes covered various topics, including defining wellbeing, setting boundaries, managing stress, and creating a positive work environment. Participants emphasized the importance of achieving stability in economic, physical, and social aspects for overall wellbeing. They discussed the significance of work-life balance and the need for a supportive and safe work environment.

The panelists shared their experiences and strategies for promoting wellbeing. They highlighted the need for open communication, positive relationships, and work-life integration. Setting boundaries and prioritizing tasks were seen as crucial to managing workload and stress effectively. Participants also acknowledged the role of managers in creating a culture of wellbeing and the responsibility of individuals in taking care of their own wellbeing.

The discussion explored various practices and concepts related to wellbeing, including the importance of rest, personal development goals, and reflection. Participants emphasized the need for a holistic approach to wellbeing, considering physical, mental, emotional, and spiritual aspects. They also discussed the value of working on projects aligned with personal values and contributing to the community.

The meeting notes concluded with participants sharing inspiring quotes, references, and wellbeing practices. Maya Angelou's quote, "When I knew better - I did better," resonated with the idea of continuous improvement. References to books like "Essentialism" by Greg McKeown and "The five major pieces to the life puzzle" by Jim Rohn were also mentioned.

Overall, the collaborative notes from the EON Thriving Together ToT Open House provided valuable insights into fostering wellbeing and engagement in organizations. The discussions emphasized the need for a supportive work environment, effective stress management, and the alignment of personal values with professional goals to achieve sustainable impact.
can you give me a list of topics and then inside each topic a summary of what was said and who said it?

Certainly! Here's a list of topics discussed during the EON Thriving Together ToT Open House, along with a summary of the key points shared by participants:

**Topic: Defining Wellbeing**
- Participants highlighted the importance of stability in economic, physical, and social aspects for overall wellbeing. (Milia, Aya, Rim)
- Wellbeing is an ongoing process that requires adapting approaches based on unique needs and challenges. (Sarah)
- Wellbeing encompasses internal and external factors that contribute to a state of peace and harmony. (Aya)

**Topic: Setting Boundaries**
- Participants discussed the challenges of setting boundaries in a work environment where immediate responses are expected. (Rim)
- Establishing clear boundaries and communicating availability only during work hours helps manage expectations. (Rim)
- Support systems and mutual respect across departments can assist in setting and maintaining boundaries. (Rim)

**Topic: Managing Stress**
- Stress was identified as a significant factor affecting wellbeing, particularly in the workplace. (Aya, Mohammed Alafifi)
- Strategies for stress management included workload management, time management, and having a personal toolkit for challenging situations. (Munir)
- Stress can manifest in both mental and physical ways, highlighting the importance of holistic wellbeing. (Participants)

**Topic: Work-Life Balance**
- Work-life balance was emphasized as a crucial aspect of wellbeing. (Peter, Dima, Aya)
- Participants discussed the need to prioritize personal and family time alongside professional responsibilities. (Peter, Dima)
- Finding a balance between work and personal life was seen as mutually beneficial, enhancing overall wellbeing. (Dima)

**Topic: Personal Development Goals**
- Participants encouraged individuals to consider personal development goals alongside professional goals. (Aya)
- Identifying areas for growth and pursuing skills and knowledge aligned with personal interests and passions were highlighted. (Aya, Peter)

**Topic: Values and Beliefs**
- The importance of aligning work with personal values and contributing to causes that make a positive impact was discussed. (Layal, Bilal)
- Creating and exchanging values were seen as ways to foster economies and create meaningful change. (Bilal, Mohammed Sikka)

**Topic: Promoting a Positive Work Environment**
- The role of managers in creating a culture of wellbeing and supporting employee engagement was emphasized. (Annie)
- A supportive work environment, open communication, and positive relationships were seen as essential for wellbeing. (Rim, Bilal)
- Recognizing and valuing the human aspect of work contributed to a positive and thriving work environment. (Rim)

**Topic: Wellbeing Practices**
- Participants shared various wellbeing practices, including rest, reflection, and self-care. (Layal, Dara, Mohammed/Layal)
- Taking breaks, having designated time off, and creating supportive community check-in channels were mentioned. (Dara, Mohammed/Layal)
- Participants emphasized the importance of self-reflection and making smart decisions to align personal and professional lives. (DMN, Mohammed Alafifi)

Please note that these summaries are a condensed version of the meeting notes and may not capture every detail or perspective shared during the discussions.
